repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
Issue #34816, Neovim with FAR Manager + ConEmu

Solution:
Disable OSC 52 when the terminal is ConEmu and ConEmuHk is enabled

comment_data.body: why not add this to the condition on line 25 ? or line 10, if line 25 is not appropriate.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,6 +29,10 @@ vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
       return
     end
 
+    if os.getenv('ConEmuHooks') == 'Enabled' then

comment_data.body:
No strong reason, I wasn't sure what is the preferred practice in neovim.
I tried to separate concerns.

I merged the test into the one at line 10.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -29,6 +29,10 @@ vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
       return
     end
 
+    if os.getenv('ConEmuHooks') == 'Enabled' then

comment_regular_data.body:
I see no reason for FreeBSD to fail.

---

If it helps I can create and share an animated gif with the fix applied.

The fix tested (directly in an installed version of Neovim):
https://mihai-nita.net/tmp/neovim/NeovimFarConemu_FgColors_Fix.gif

@gpanders we have a terminal.app check here, isn't that a good place for this kind of workaround? https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/88925cf5f37ca5678259b8a037fb0778bce70b69/runtime/plugin/osc52.lua#L29-L30

**Note:** I have zero familiarity with neovim, or lua.
I only started from the commit that introduced the problem to begin with, and that changed `osc52.lua`.
So if you have any idea on how to approach this, I am happy to do it that way.

> Why do we need this? OSC 52 is only enabled if the terminal indicates support. And why is the option to explicitly disable OSC 52 manually not sufficient?

How is a terminal indicating support?

The terminal definitions (including `conemu_terminfo`) seem to be in `src\nvim\tui\terminfo_defs.h`, but there is no indicator for osc 52 support (that I can see).

I also tried storing something in the clipboard directly with the escape sequences under FAR + ConEmu
(`echo "]52;p;SGVsbG8gd29ybGQ=\\"`)
And does not work. So I assume ConEmu does not support OSC 52.

Also a search on the ConEmu website, and the sources, does not mention anything about "OSC"

So at this point I assume that ConEmu does not support OSC 52, and the problem is how to pass that info to Neovim.

I also checked the dependencies, and `unibilium` knows nothing about conemu.

> @gpanders we have a terminal.app check here, isn't that a good place for this kind of workaround?
> 
> https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/88925cf5f37ca5678259b8a037fb0778bce70b69/runtime/plugin/osc52.lua#L29-L30

That's true, I forgot about this. However, I'd still rather ask @mihnita to set `vim.g.termfeatures = { osc52 = false }` to disable the query, rather than introduce code to work around a bug caused by DLL injection of all things.

I tried to also see if I can figure out the root cause.

And I removed most of the code in `vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {`:

This works:
```
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
  group = id,
  desc = 'Enable OSC 52 feature flag if a supporting TUI is attached',
  callback = function()
    return
  end,
})
```

This still has a problem:
```
vim.api.nvim_create_autocmd('UIEnter', {
  group = id,
  desc = 'Enable OSC 52 feature flag if a supporting TUI is attached',
  callback = function()
    require('vim.termcap').query('Ms', function(cap, found, seq)
      return
    end)
  end,
})
```

So it is like `require('vim.termcap').query('Ms'` is failing somehow.
But I don't know how that works.

Is it possible the query (in `runtime\lua\vim\termcap.lua` ?) fails somehow when using `XTGETTCAP DCS` with ConEmu?

I tried sending raw escapes (`echo "P+q4D73\"`) from ConEmu + FAR. It does not hang. But it does not answer with a string.

So I would assume that ConEmu does not support `XTGETTCAP`.

I confirm that adding `vim.g.termfeatures = { osc52 = false }` to my config solves the problem.

> a bug caused by DLL injection of all things.

But we don't really know that, it is an educated guess.
I was unable to trigger any problems sending XTGETTCAP and OSC 52 sequences to ConEmu.

Let's assume it is a bug in ConEmu...
Does it mean that anyone using the combination I use is left to manually implement the workaround in their config?

I don't know the neovim policies.

But my guess is that _"we don't implement workarounds for terminal bugs"_ as a general policy means that most terminals will not work. Since there is no terminal without bugs :-)

Options (that I can see):
- Implement a workaround (we don't know 100% sure if it really is a ConEmu bug).
  That means most Neovim users will not notice any problem.
- Try to find the cause in ConEmu, file a bug, wait for a new release, and hope all Neovim users install the latest and greatest ConEmu release
- Just document the `vim.g.termfeatures = { osc52 = false }` workaround, don't do anything else
- Don't even document the workaround, let people out to dry for months (the way I was)
- Some combination of the above

---

I would implement a workaround.
But I am (of course :-) not in the position to make such decisions.
100% your call.

If you decide to accept a workaround, I am happy to make it in a way that you find satisfactory.

And if not, is is of course your prerogative, and I defer to your decision.

Regards,
Mihai

> Does it mean that anyone using the combination I use is left to manually implement the workaround in their config?

Does the workaround (`getenv('ConEmuHooks') == 'Enabled'`) disable osc52 for all conemnu users, or only users that enable the DLL injection? 

If it only affects the dll injection victims, I think this PR is fine. Not worth spending more time on this.

> Does the workaround (getenv('ConEmuHooks') == 'Enabled') disable osc52 for all conemnu users, or only users that enable the DLL injection?

Only for people with ConEmu AND with DLL injection enabled.
But that is the default, and without it quite a few things don't work.
So I suppose most people will have it enabled, if they don't have any problems.

Although it is probably safe to disable it for all ConEmu users, since ConEmu does not support neither OSC 52 nor XTGETTCAP (I've spent the last hour or so in the ConEmu sources).

---

:-(

Correction: the environment variable `ConEmuHooks` seems to be set to `Enabled` even when I uncheck the option in Settings.
I tried it in ConEmu in combination with `FAR`, `Powershell`, and `cmd.exe`.

I can't find any way to detect if hooks are enabled or not, and I can't tell if this is a bug or not.

Looks like `ConEmuHooks` is used one-way.
One can set it to influence the execution of applications started:
https://conemu.github.io/en/ConEmuEnvironment.html#Disabling_hooks_temporarily

But changing it in the GUI Settings does not set the environment variable, even after restarting the console.

---

I tested the fix with and without hooks enabled, and with the `ConEmuHooks` set to all the valid values (`OFF`, `NOARG`, `NOSTART`, `Enabled`).

> ConEmu does not support neither OSC 52 nor XTGETTCAP
>
> ... `ConEmuHooks` seems to be set to `Enabled` even when I uncheck the option in Settings.

ðŸ‘€

title: fix(osc52): no foreground colors in FAR+ConEmu
